Page.title: Federal Income and the GDP
Page.description: The United States collected $3.4 trillion in 2017, 17% of the GDP.
Page._content:
In 2017, the government collected $3.3 trillion

Most of the federal government's income comes from federal taxes.

Most federal income comes from contributions from individuals and small businesses. Along with federal income taxes, the government collects payroll taxes. You may recognize these taxes on your paycheck that help fund programs such as Social Security, Medicare, and Unemployment Insurance. Also, corporations pay taxes as part of doing business in the United States.

The remaining sources of government income consist of excise, estate, and other taxes and fees.

How does the amount of federal income compare to the size of the economy?

Data Provided by: Bureau of Economic Analysis

In Fiscal Year 2017, the total GDP of the U.S. was $19.5 trillion.

The government collected the equivalent of 17% of GDP.

What's GDP?

What are the sources of government income?

Continue
Data Provided by: Bureau of Economic Analysis

How much is $3.3 trillion? It is equivalent to a little more than $10,000 for every individual in the U.S. ($3.3 trillion divided by the U.S. population estimate in 2017, 325.7 million U.S. Census Bureau.)

Gross Domestic Product (GDP) measures the size of the nation's economy in terms of the total value of goods and services that are produced in a year. Measuring the money collected by the government relative to GDP is a helpful indicator of the economy's capacity to sustain the programs the government provides for the people and the government's success in helping the economy grow.

In this analysis, each dot represents $1 billion. Each dot represents contributions to the government from you, your family, your neighbors, your place of business, and the corporations you deal with every day.
Page.raw:

Page.title: Federal Income Categories
Page.description: This is the text that goes in the meta description tag
Page._content:
This is where the $3.3 trillion comes from.

Income by Source Categories

Click to explore sub-categories.

The $3.3 trillion the government collected last year keeps the federal government in operation.

Most government income collected comes from individual taxpayers, small businesses, and corporations through taxes that get collected on a yearly or quarterly basis.

Other sources of income include money collected from excise taxes, estate taxes, and customs duties. Government income also comes from payments to federal agencies like the Post Office who sell products or services to the public, like stamps. Have you visited a national park recently?

What makes up individual income taxes? How much money is contributed by Social Security, Medicare, and General Retirement? What's included in the 12% of income that doesn't come from taxpayers or corporations. Find out more below.

How does the amount of federal income compare to the size of the economy?

Click the chart to dive deeper into the various sources of government income, including additional income sources outside of federal taxes.

How has government income changed over time?

When you're done here, explore the trends in federal income over the past five years.

Continue

Not all federal income comes from taxes! Your national park entry fee also goes towards government income.

All data shown is from Fiscal Year 2017.

Data provided by the Monthly Treasury Statement supplied by the Bureau of the Fiscal Service, U.S. Department of the Treasury.

Page.title: Trends in Federal Income Categories
Page.description: This is the text that goes in the meta description tag
Page._content:
Federal Income Trends over Time From 2013 – 2017

How has federal income changed over the past few years?

The chart below shows the various source categories for federal income over a five year period. Click a category to view income by subcategory. What changes have occurred over the past five years? What impact do changes in a subcategory have on government income?

Explore for yourself!

Click a category below to see how subcategories have contributed to the trends over the past five years.

How does the income of the United States compare to other countries?

When you're done here, see how income collected by the U.S. government compares to other countries.

Continue

Income over Time by Category

Click an income category to view more

All data shown is from Fiscal Year 2017.

Income for prior years adjusted for inflation to September 2017 dollars.

Data provided by the Monthly Treasury Statement supplied by the Bureau of the Fiscal Service, U.S. Department of the Treasury.

Page.title: Federal Income Country Comparison
Page.description: This is the text that goes in the meta description tag
Page._content:
Compare the Income of the United States to other Countries.

The chart below shows income collected by the U.S. government compared to 171 other countries in 2017. In that same year, the government collected $3.3 trillion, which is equivalent to 17% of total GDP.

How does the U.S. compare to other countries? We encourage you to check out the chart below. You can compare total income (in dollars) and income as a percent of GDP. Pick a country of interest and see for yourself.

Country Comparison

Click to sort columns.
All data is representative of FY 2017. Data provided by
